doc.title: US Daily: Lessons from the Papers Presented at Jackson Hole

passages.text: The Fed's Jackson Hole symposium featured a panel discussion on AI and presentations of several research papers that offered lessons about the long- run outlook for the U.S. economy.

Nakamura et al. note that during the pandemic, the Fed and other central banks raised interest rates much less than standard monetary policy rules would have suggested but did not lose control of long- run inflation expectations. They attribute this to central banks' inflation- fighting credentials and argue that a weaker response to inflation shocks is appropriate when they are transitory and "long and variable lags" would limit the impact of hikes in counteracting them.

Auclert et al. conclude that since the 1950s, population aging, increasing inequality, falling productivity growth, and rising foreign demand have raised U.S. asset demand and reduced interest rates. Their model suggests that population aging will increase asset demand enough by 2100 that interest rates would remain stable even if debt- to- GDP rose to \(250\%\) , as long as deficit- reduction policies are implemented to limit or offset the growth of entitlement program costs.

Foschi et al. find that U.S. inter- state migration has declined moderately over the past 50 years, but the elasticity of net migration to labor demand shocks has remained stable, suggesting that workers are not "stuck" and still respond to local economic shocks by relocating to other states.

Goldin argues that a key driver of the global decline in fertility rates has been greater female autonomy not accompanied by commitments to share childcare responsibilities within couples or government support for childcare, and that the decline will continue absent changes to guarantee more support to women.

The four economic research papers presented at the Fed's Jackson Hole meeting this year offered lessons about the long- term outlook for the U.S. economy. The papers provide insights into monetary policy during the recent inflation surge, future challenges for fiscal policy, geographic mobility in the labor market, and fertility and long- term population growth.

Emi Nakamura, Venance Riblier and Jon Steinsson's paper "Beyond the Taylor Rule" discusses how the Federal Reserve managed to "look through" the post- pandemic inflation by tightening policy less than implied by standard monetary policy rules like the Taylor Rule. The paper shows that deviations from the Taylor Rule have occurred frequently since the 1990s but argues that this is not evidence of suboptimal monetary policy. Several reasons explain why central banks might choose to respond to inflation by less than implied by standard rules, including the "long and variable lags" of policy that imply central banks should not try to fully offset transitory shocks because rate hikes would affect the economy too slowly to counteract them anyway.

The authors argue that a key reason that inflation did not get out of control despite the more limited monetary policy response by the Fed and other central banks with strong inflation- fighting track records is that their credibility was strong enough to maintain control of long- run inflation expectations. In contrast, central banks with weaker track records tended to tighten sooner and more aggressively but nonetheless experienced larger inflation spikes.

Adrien Auclerth, Hannes Malmberg, Matthew Rognlie and Ludwig Straub's paper "The Race Between Asset Supply and Asset Demand" introduces a quantitative economic model where changes in long- run interest rates are driven by the balance between asset supply and demand, and uses it to discuss the past and future of the U.S. fiscal position. Since the 1950s, demographic changes, increasing inequality, falling productivity growth, and strong foreign demand have all supported U.S. asset demand. Supply has picked up since the 1980s, driven by rising government debt, but demand dominated, putting downward pressure on interest rates.

- Their model suggests that population aging will raise the demand for government debt over the next few decades, but they note that demographics will also impact the debt supply through the fiscal burden of welfare programs like Social Security and Medicare. Surprisingly, their model suggests that population aging will boost asset demand enough by 2100 that interest rates would remain stable even if debt-to-GDP rose to 250%, but only if aggressive deficit-reduction policies are implemented. In her discussion of the paper, Karen Dynan noted that this conclusion critically depends on assuming a very low sensitivity of interest rates to debt increases. We have likewise assumed a slightly higher sensitivity in our recent work on fiscal sustainability, which would likely imply an unsustainable fiscal trajectory at such debt levels.
Andrea Foschi, Christopher House, Christian Proebsting and Linda Tesar's paper "Inter- state Labor Mobility and the U.S. Economy" examines long- run trends in the

geographic mobility of US workers. They find that gross migration rates have fallen over the past 50 years, but only moderately, due to a decline in "offsetting migration" or churn—migration flows between states matched by reverse flows that leave state populations unchanged in control, net migration flows—those that change state populations—have regained state.

They also find that the elasticity of net migration to labor demand shocks has not declined, suggesting that workers are not stuck in place, say due to mortgage lock- in, and still respond to local economic shocks by relocating to other states. However, their analysis indicates that the incentives to relocate may have diminished as the industrial composition of states has grown more homogeneous and economic shocks have become more geographically correlated.

Claudia Goldin's paper "The Downside of Fertility" investigates the drivers behind the global decline in fertility rates, noting that in advanced economies rates have been below the replacement ratio of 2.1 since the 1980s. In the U.S., the fertility rate has been mostly below replacement level since 1972 and is currently slightly above 1.5. She argues that fertility declines tend to follow improvements in women's employment, education, and reproductive rights, which allow for greater freedom in marriage and childbearing choices. Her main point is that such improvements create a mismatch within couples if men do not increase their contribution to household and childcare responsibilities, leading to delays in having children or to the decision of not having them.

Goldin concludes that greater female autonomy, without commitments to share childcare responsibilities within couples and government support for childcare, will lead to even lower birth rates in the future.

In addition to the papers presented, the Jackson Hole meeting featured an academic panel that discussed the impact of technology on the labor market with a focus on AI. Lawrence Katz noted that early evidence suggests that generative AI increases productivity in a few tasks—such as professional writing, customer support, and software development—with large gains for novice and less skilled workers, though the impact on employment and wages has still been limited. As our Global Economics team recently noted, we do not expect large AI- driven employment reductions over the next decade, primarily because AI innovation will likely create new work opportunities that help offset job losses from automation. Laura Veldkamp emphasized that the extent to which workers' real wages will rise will depend on whether competition prevents AI companies from accruing most of the productivity increase as profit.
Auclert, Adrien, Hannes Malmberg, Matthew Rognlie and Ludwig Straub, "The Race Between Asset Supply and Asset Demand," 2025
Foschi, Andrea, Christopher House, Christian Proebsting and Linda Tesar, "Inter- state Labor Mobility and the U.S. Economy," 2025
Goldin, Claudia, "The Downside of Fertility," 2025
Nakamura, Emi, Venance Riblier and Jón Steinsson, "Beyond the Taylor Rule," 2025

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.
